dialogs.original: Will you think so?
dialogs.translated: Do you think so?

dialogs.original: Think so, Iago?
dialogs.translated: Think what, Iago?

dialogs.original: What,To kiss in private?
dialogs.translated: What, that they kissed in private?

dialogs.original: An unauthorized kiss!
dialogs.translated: An inappropriate kiss!

dialogs.original: Or to be naked with her friend in bedAn hour or more, not meaning any harm?
dialogs.translated: Or because she was naked in bed with a friend for just an hour or more, not meaning any harm?

dialogs.original: Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm!    It is hypocrisy against the devil.    They that mean virtuously, and yet do so,    The devil their virtue tempts, and they tempt heaven.
dialogs.translated: Iago, naked in bed and not meaning any harm? That would be like tricking the devil. If they were acting this way but had virtuous intentions, they were tempted by the devil and they were tempting God to damn them.

dialogs.original: So they do nothing, tis a venial slip. But if I give my wife a handkerchief
dialogs.translated: As long as they haven't actually done anything, it's just a pardonable sin. But, if I give my wife a handkerchief . . .

dialogs.original: What then?
dialogs.translated: What then?

dialogs.original: Why then tis hers, my lord, and, being hers,She may, I think, bestow t on any man.
dialogs.translated: Then it belongs to her, my lord. And since it is hers, she may give it to any man she wants.

dialogs.original: She is protectress of her honor too. May she give that?
dialogs.translated: Her honor belongs to her, too. Can she give that away, as well?

dialogs.original: Her honor is an essence thats not seen,They have it very oft that have it not.But for the handkerchief
dialogs.translated: Her honor is part of her inner essence that can't be seen. Often people have an honorable reputation but aren't really honorable. But as for the handkerchief

dialogs.original: By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it.    Thou saidstOh, it comes o'er my memory,    As doth the raven o'er the infectious house,    Boding to allhe had my handkerchief.
dialogs.translated: By heaven, I wish I had forgotten about it. You told meoh, it comes back to my memory, like the bad omen of a raven coming over a house where someone is sickthat Cassio had my handkerchief.

dialogs.original: Ay, what of that?
dialogs.translated: Yes, so what?

dialogs.original: Thats not so good now.
dialogs.translated: That is not so good, now.

dialogs.original: What if I had said I had seen him do you wrong?    Or heard him sayas knaves be such abroad,    Who having, by their own importunate suit,    Or voluntary dotage of some mistress,    Convincèd or supplied them, cannot choose    But they must blab
dialogs.translated: What if I had told you that I saw him do you wrong? Or what if I heard him say sothere are some villains out there who, once they have seduced or satisfied some mistress with their flirting and doting, can't help but brag about it

dialogs.original: Hath he said any thing?
dialogs.translated: Has he said something?

dialogs.original: He hath, my lord, but be you well assuredNo more than hell unswear.
dialogs.translated: My lord, he hasbut you can be sure that he'll deny it.

dialogs.original: What hath he said?
dialogs.translated: What did he say?

dialogs.original: Why, that he didI know not what he did.
dialogs.translated: Well, he said that he didI don't know what he did.

dialogs.original: What? what?
dialogs.translated: What? What?

dialogs.original: Lie
dialogs.translated: He said he did lie

dialogs.original: With her?
dialogs.translated: With Desdemona?

dialogs.original: With her, on her, what you will.
dialogs.translated: With her, on her, however you want to say it.

dialogs.original: Lie with her? lie on her? We say lie on her when theybelie her! Lie with herthats fulsome. Handkerchiefconfessionshandkerchief!   To confess, and be hanged for his labor.   First to be hanged, and then toconfessI tremble at it   .   Nature would not invest herself in such shadowing passion without some instruction. It is not words that shake me thus. Pish! Noses, ears, and lips. Is t possible? Confess!Handkerchief!Oh, devil!
dialogs.translated: Lie with her? Lie on her? To lie on someone is to tell lies about that person! To lie with herthat's obscene. First the handkerchief, and now this confession! Should he confess first and then be executed? No, I'll kill him first and let him confess later. I am trembling with anger, and nature wouldn't make my body do this without some reason. It must be more than a rumor if it's making me tremble like this. Ugh! Noses, ears, and lips. Could this be true? That he would admit to itand the handkerchief! Oh, devil!

dialogs.original: Work on, My medicine, work! Thus credulous fools are caught,    And many worthy and chaste dames even thus,    All guiltless, meet reproach.   What, ho! My lord!    My lord, I say! Othello!
dialogs.translated: [To himself] Keep on working, my harmful medicine, keep on working! This is how gullible fools are tricked, and many trustworthy and chaste women, completely innocent, are punished in situations like this. [To OTHELLO] Hey! My lord! My lord! Othello!

dialogs.original: How now, Cassio!
dialogs.translated: Hey there, Cassio!

dialogs.original: Whats the matter?
dialogs.translated: What's the matter?

dialogs.original: My lord is fall'n into an epilepsy.This is his second fit. He had one yesterday.
dialogs.translated: My lord has fallen into a seizure. This is the second time he's had one of these fits. He had one yesterday.

dialogs.original: Rub him about the temples.
dialogs.translated: Rub his temples.

dialogs.original: No, forbear.    The lethargy must have his quiet course.    If not, he foams at mouth and by and by    Breaks out to savage madness. Look, he stirs.    Do you withdraw yourself a little while,    He will recover straight. When he is gone    I would on great occasion speak with you.
dialogs.translated: No, hold on. We have to let the fit run its course. Otherwise he'll foam at the mouth and break out in a fit of savage madness. Look, he's moving. Stay away for a bit. He'll recover soon. When he is gone, I would really like to talk to you in private.

dialogs.original: How is it, general? Have you not hurt your head?
dialogs.translated: How are you, General? Have you hurt your head?

dialogs.original: Dost thou mock me?
dialogs.translated: Are you mocking me?

dialogs.original: I mock you not, by heaven.Would you would bear your fortune like a man!
dialogs.translated: No, I swear to God! I wish you would bear your misfortune like a man!

dialogs.original: A hornèd mans a monster and a beast.
dialogs.translated: A man who's been cheated on isn't a man; he has the cuckold's horns, and so is a monstrous beast.

dialogs.original: Theres many a beast then in a populous city,And many a civil monster.
dialogs.translated: Well then, there are many monsters in big cities, and many monsters that pass for men.

dialogs.original: Did he confess it?
dialogs.translated: Did Cassio confess to it?

dialogs.original: Good sir, be a man,    Think every bearded fellow thats but yoked    May draw with you.   Theres millions now alive    That nightly lie in those unproper beds    Which they dare swear peculiar. Your case is better.    Oh, tis the spite of hell, the fiends arch-mock,    To lip a wanton in a secure couch,    And to suppose her chaste.   No, let me know,    And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.
dialogs.translated: Good sir, be a man. Think about it: every married man has experienced what you're going through. There are millions of wives now living who sleep in disgraced beds which they swear belong only to their husbands. But you're better off. It's even worsea curse from hellto kiss your wife in bed thinking that she is chaste when she isn't. No, I'd rather know if my wife were cheating on me. Then I'd know exactly what sort of person I am and what sort of person my wife is.

dialogs.original: Oh, thou art wise! 'Tis certain.
dialogs.translated: Oh, you are certainly wise!

dialogs.original: Stand you awhile apart,    Confine yourself but in a patient list.    Whilst you were here o'erwhelmèd with your grief    A passion most resulting such a man    Cassio came hither. I shifted him away    And laid good scuses upon your ecstasy,    Bade him anon return and here speak with me,    The which he promised. Do but encave yourself,    And mark the fleers, the gibes, and notable scorns    That dwell in every region of his face.    For I will make him tell the tale anew    Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when    He hath, and is again to cope your wife.    I say, but mark his gesture. Marry, patience,    Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen,    And nothing of a man.
dialogs.translated: Stay away from her for a while. Be patient. While you were overwhelmed by your griefa passionate feeling you are prone toCassio was here. I sent him away and made some excuse for your fit of passion. I told him to come back here and speak with me, and he promised to do so. Hide nearby and watch the sneers and visible expressions of scorn all over his face, as I ask him to tell me again about where, how, how often, how long ago, and when he has slept and will again sleep with your wife. Just watch his expression. Please, be patient, or else you'll show that you are completely ruled by your emotions and not a real man.

dialogs.original: Dost thou hear, Iago?I will be found most cunning in my patience,Butdost thou hear?most bloody.
dialogs.translated: Listen to me, Iago: I will be patient and cunning. Butdo you hear me?I will take violent action later.

dialogs.original: Thats not amiss, But yet keep time in all. Will you withdraw?
dialogs.translated: That's not wrong. But wait for a bit. Will you step back and hide?

dialogs.original: Now will I question Cassio of Bianca,    A huswife that by selling her desires    Buys herself bread and clothes.   It is a creature    That dotes on Cassio, as tis the strumpets plague    To beguile many and be beguiled by one.    He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain    From the excess of laughter. Here he comes.
dialogs.translated: Now I will question Cassio about Bianca, a loose girl that makes a living by selling herself to men. The whore loves Cassio, and it's her bad luck to attract many men but be attracted to just one. When he is asked about her, he can't help but laugh. Here he comes.

dialogs.original: As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad.    And his unbookish jealousy must construe    Poor Cassios smiles, gestures, and light behavior    Quite in the wrong.   How do you now, lieutenant?
dialogs.translated: [To himself] As Cassio smiles while we talk, Othello will go mad. And his unrestrained jealousy will misinterpret poor Cassio's smiles, gestures, and jovial behavior. [To CASSIO] How are you doing now, lieutenant?

dialogs.original: The worser that you give me the additionWhose want even kills me.
dialogs.translated: I'm doing worse now since you called me lieutenant, when it's killing me that I don't have that title anymore.

dialogs.original: Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure on t. Now if this suit lay in Biancas powerHow quickly should you speed!
dialogs.translated: Ask Desdemona to help you, and you'll surely get it back. [To CASSIO so only he can hear] Now, if it were Bianca who had the power to help you, I imagine you'd be running off to her as fast as you could!

dialogs.original: Alas, poor caitiff!
dialogs.translated: Ha, that poor woman!

dialogs.original: Look how he laughs already!
dialogs.translated: Look how he's laughing already!

dialogs.original: I never knew woman love man so.
dialogs.translated: I've never seen a woman love a man as much as she loves you.

dialogs.original: Alas, poor rogue, I think indeed she loves me.
dialogs.translated: Alas, the poor girl, I think she really does love me.

dialogs.original: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.
dialogs.translated: Now he denies his crime a bit, and laughs it off.

dialogs.original: Do you hear, Cassio?
dialogs.translated: Have you heard, Cassio?

dialogs.original: Now he importunes himTo tell it o'er. Go to, well said, well said.
dialogs.translated: Now Iago is asking Cassio to tell the story again. Go on, well said, well said.

dialogs.original: She gives it out that you shall marry her.Do you intend it?
dialogs.translated: She is saying that you're going to marry her. Do you intend to?

dialogs.original: Ha, ha, ha!
dialogs.translated: Ha, ha, ha!

dialogs.original: Do ye triumph, Roman? Do you triumph?
dialogs.translated: Are you celebrating like a triumphant Roman general? Are you triumphing after your conquest?

dialogs.original: I marry her! What? A customer? Prithee bear some charity to my wit. Do not think it so unwholesome. Ha, ha, ha!
dialogs.translated: Me, marry her? A prostitute? Please, think a little more highly of me; don't think I'm that stupid. Ha, ha, ha!

dialogs.original: So, so, so, so! They laugh that win!
dialogs.translated: Aha, so there! He's laughing like he's won her over!

dialogs.original: Faith, the cry goes that you shall marry her.
dialogs.translated: Really, rumor has it that you are going to marry her.

dialogs.original: Prithee say true!
dialogs.translated: Please, is that true?

dialogs.original: I am a very villain else.
dialogs.translated: I swear it is, or else I'm a villain.

dialogs.original: Have you scored me? Well.
dialogs.translated: Have you wronged me? Well, then.

dialogs.original: This is the monkeys own giving out. She is persuaded Iwill marry her, out of her own love and flattery, not out of my promise.
dialogs.translated: The monkey herself must be spreading this rumor. She is convinced I will marry her, driven by her own love and self-flattery. I haven't promised her anything.

dialogs.original: Iago beckons me. Now he begins the story.
dialogs.translated: Iago is signaling to me. Now Cassio is beginning the story.

dialogs.original: She was here even now. She haunts me in every place. I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with certain Venetians, and thither comes the bauble and, by this hand, she falls me thus about my neck
dialogs.translated: She was here just now. She follows me everywhere. The other day I was talking along the shore with some Venetians, and the silly girl came to me andI swearshe hangs around my neck like this

dialogs.original: Crying O dear Cassio! as it were. His gesture importsit.
dialogs.translated: He looks like he's crying out, "Oh dear Cassio!" That's what his gestures indicate.

dialogs.original: So hangs and lolls and weeps upon me, so shakes, and pulls me! Ha, ha, ha!
dialogs.translated: She hangs on me like this and cries on my shoulder and shakes and pulls me like this! Ha, ha, ha!

dialogs.original: Now he tells how she plucked him to my chamber. Oh, I see that nose of yours, but not that dog I shall throw it to.
dialogs.translated: Now he's talking about how she dragged him to my bedroom. Oh, Cassio, I'm going to cut off your nose and throw it to some dog.

dialogs.original: Well, I must leave her company.
dialogs.translated: Well, I must stop spending time with her.

dialogs.original: Before me! Look, where she comes.
dialogs.translated: My goodness! Look, she's coming.

dialogs.original: 'Tis such another fitchew. Marry, a perfumed one.What do you mean by this haunting of me?
dialogs.translated: Just the prostitute we were talking about. And she's wearing perfume. Why are you following me around like this?

dialogs.original: Let the devil and his dam haunt you! What did you mean by that same handkerchief you gave me even now? I was a fine fool to take it. I must take out the work?   A likelypiece of work, that you should find it in your chamber,and not know who left it there! This is some minxs token, and I must take out the work? There, give it yourhobby-horse. Wheresoever you had it, Ill take out no work on t.
dialogs.translated: Let the devil and his wife follow you around! Why did you give me that handkerchief just recently? I was an idiot to accept it. You want me to copy the embroidery? What a likely story, that you found it in your room and didn't know who left it there! This is a gift from some woman, and you want me to copy out the embroidery? There, give it back to your new mistress. Wherever you got it from, I'm not copying any of it.

dialogs.original: How now, my sweet Bianca! How now, how now?
dialogs.translated: What's the matter, my sweet Bianca? What's the matter?

dialogs.original: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!
dialogs.translated: By heaven, that's my handkerchief!

dialogs.original: If youll come to supper tonight, you may. If you will not, come when you are next prepared for.
dialogs.translated: If you will come have dinner with me tonight, then okay. If you don't come to dinner then just keep on waiting until I call for you nextwhich will be never.

dialogs.original: After her, after her.
dialogs.translated: Go after her, go after her.

dialogs.original: I must, shell rail in the street else.
dialogs.translated: I must. Otherwise, she'll make a ruckus in the street.

dialogs.original: Will you sup there?
dialogs.translated: Will you go to dinner with her?

dialogs.original: Yes, I intend so.
dialogs.translated: Yes, I intend to go.

dialogs.original: Well, I may chance to see you, for I would very fain speak with you.
dialogs.translated: Well, I'd like to get a chance to see you later, because I really would like to speak with you.

dialogs.original: Prithee come, will you?
dialogs.translated: Please come to the diner, then. Will you?

dialogs.original: Go to! Say no more.
dialogs.translated: Stop talking and go after her!

dialogs.original: [advancing]  How shall I murder him, Iago?
dialogs.translated: [Coming forward out of hiding] How should I murder him, Iago?

dialogs.original: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?
dialogs.translated: Did you see how he laughed about his crime?

dialogs.original: Oh Iago!
dialogs.translated: Oh, Iago!

dialogs.original: And did you see the handkerchief?
dialogs.translated: And did you see the handkerchief?

dialogs.original: Was that mine?
dialogs.translated: Was that my handkerchief?

dialogs.original: Yours by this hand. And to see how he prizes the foolish woman your wife! She gave it him, and he hath given it his whore.
dialogs.translated: I swear on my hand, it was yours. And look how much he cares about your foolish wife! She gave him her handkerchief, and he turns around and gives it to a whore.

dialogs.original: I would have him nine years a-killing. A fine woman! A fair woman! A sweet woman!
dialogs.translated: If I could, I'd spend nine years killing him slowly. She was a fine woman! A beautiful woman! A sweet woman!

dialogs.original: Nay, you must forget that.
dialogs.translated: You must forget about that.

dialogs.original: Ay, let her rot and perish and be damned tonight, for she shall not live. No, my heart is turned to stone. I strike it and it hurts my hand.   Oh, the world hath not asweeter creature, she might lie by an emperors side and command him tasks.
dialogs.translated: Yes, let her rot and perish and go to hell tonight, for she will not live past tonight. No, my heart has turned to stone. If I beat my chest, it hurts my hand. Oh, there's not a sweeter creature in the world! She could be the wife of an emperor and he'd obey her commands.

dialogs.original: Nay, thats not your way.
dialogs.translated: No, that's not like you to obey a woman.

dialogs.original: Hang her! I do but say what she is. So delicate with her needle, an admirable musician. Oh, she will sing thesavageness out of a bear! Of so high and plenteous wit and invention!
dialogs.translated: Let her be hanged! I'm just calling her what she is now. Such a skilled sewer, such an admirable musician. Oh, she could sing so well she'd charm a savage bear to gentleness! She's so clever and intelligent!

dialogs.original: Shes the worse for all this.
dialogs.translated: All these traits make her even worse.

dialogs.original: Oh, a thousand thousand timesand then of so gentle a condition!
dialogs.translated: Oh, they make her a thousand times worse! And she has such a gentle nature!

dialogs.original: Ay, too gentle.
dialogs.translated: Yes, too gentle.

dialogs.original: Nay, thats certain. But yet the pity of it, Iago! O Iago, the pity of it, Iago!
dialogs.translated: That's certainly true. But what a pity this is, Iago! Oh, Iago, the pity!

dialogs.original: If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for if it touch not you it comes near nobody.
dialogs.translated: If you still care about her after her sinfulness, give her permission to cheat on you. If it doesn't bother you, it doesn't harm anyone.

dialogs.original: I will chop her into messes! Cuckold me?
dialogs.translated: I will chop her up into little bits! Cheat on me, will she?

dialogs.original: Oh, tis foul in her.
dialogs.translated: Oh, it's really a foul thing for her to do.

dialogs.original: With mine officer!
dialogs.translated: With my own lieutenant!

dialogs.original: Thats fouler.
dialogs.translated: That's even worse.

dialogs.original: Get me some poison, Iago, this night. Ill not expostulate with her, lest her body and beauty unprovidemy mind againThis night, Iago!
dialogs.translated: Iago, get me some poison this very night. I won't speak to her, so her body and beauty don't trick my mind again. Get me the poison tonight, Iago!

dialogs.original: Do it not with poison. Strangle her in her bed, even the bed she hath contaminated.
dialogs.translated: Don't poison her. Strangle her in her bedthe very bed she contaminated with her affair.

dialogs.original: Good, good, the justice of it pleases! Very good!
dialogs.translated: Good idea! Poetic justice! Very good!

dialogs.original: And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker. You shall hear more by midnight.
dialogs.translated: And as for Cassio, let me handle him. You'll hear more about it by midnight.

dialogs.original: Excellent good.
dialogs.translated: Very good.

dialogs.original: What trumpet is that same?
dialogs.translated: What is that trumpet?

dialogs.original: I warrant something from Venice. 'Tis Lodovico, this, comes from the duke. See, your wifes with him.
dialogs.translated: It must be some news from Venice. Here comes Lodovico, from the Duke. Look, your wife is with him.

dialogs.original: Save you, worthy general!
dialogs.translated: Hello, noble General.

dialogs.original: With all my heart, sir.
dialogs.translated: Hello, sir.

dialogs.original: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.
dialogs.translated: The Duke and Senators of Venice send their greetings.

dialogs.original: I kiss the instrument of their pleasures.
dialogs.translated: I kiss the letter that contains their commands.

dialogs.original: And whats the news, good cousin Lodovico?
dialogs.translated: And what's the news, good cousin Lodovico?

dialogs.original: I am very glad to see you, signior. Welcome to Cyprus.
dialogs.translated: I am very glad to see you, sir. Welcome to Cyprus.

dialogs.original: I thank you. How does lieutenant Cassio?
dialogs.translated: Thank you. How is Lieutenant Cassio doing?

dialogs.original: Lives, sir.
dialogs.translated: He's alive, sir.

dialogs.original: Cousin, theres fall'n between him and my lordAn unkind breach, but you shall make all well.
dialogs.translated: Cousin, there's a rift now between my husband and him. But you can mend it.

dialogs.original: Are you sure of that?
dialogs.translated: Are you sure about that?

dialogs.original: My lord?
dialogs.translated: My lord?

dialogs.original: [reads]  This fail you not to do, as you will
dialogs.translated: [Reading the letter] "Don't fail to do this, since you will"

dialogs.original: He did not call, hes busy in the paper.Is there division twixt my lord and Cassio?
dialogs.translated: He wasn't talking to you, Desdemona. He's busy reading the letter. Is there really a dispute between my lord and Cassio?

dialogs.original: A most unhappy one. I would do much T' atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio.
dialogs.translated: Yes, a most unhappy one. I would do anything to repair their friendship, because of my love for Cassio.

dialogs.original: Fire and brimstone!
dialogs.translated: Fire and brimstone!

dialogs.original: My lord?
dialogs.translated: My lord?

dialogs.original: Are you wise?
dialogs.translated: Do you have any sense?

dialogs.original: What, is he angry?
dialogs.translated: What, is he angry?

dialogs.original: Maybe the letter moved him,For, as I think, they do command him home,Deputing Cassio in his government.
dialogs.translated: Maybe the letter upset him. I think they've ordered him to return home and leave Cassio in charge here.

dialogs.original: By my troth, I am glad on t.
dialogs.translated: Truthfully, I'm glad about that.

dialogs.original: Indeed!
dialogs.translated: Really!

dialogs.original: My lord?
dialogs.translated: My lord?

dialogs.original: I am glad to see you mad.
dialogs.translated: I'm glad to see that you are angry.

dialogs.original: Why, sweet Othello
dialogs.translated: Why, sweet Othello

dialogs.original: Devil!  [strikes her]
dialogs.translated: You devil! [He hits DESDEMONA]

dialogs.original: I have not deserved this.
dialogs.translated: I haven't done anything to deserve this.

dialogs.original: My lord, this would not be believed in Venice,Though I should swear I saw t. 'Tis very much.Make her amends, she weeps.
dialogs.translated: My lord, no one in Venice would believe you just did thateven if I swore that I saw it with my own eyes. This is no small matter. Apologize to her. She's crying.

dialogs.original: Oh, devil, devil!    If that the earth could teem with womans tears,    Each drop she falls would prove a crocodile.    Out of my sight!
dialogs.translated: Oh, devil, devil! If the whole world were filled with the tears of women, they'd all be fake tears! Get out of my sight!

dialogs.original: I will not stay to offend you.
dialogs.translated: I will not stay, if it offends you.

dialogs.original: Truly, an obedient lady.I do beseech your lordship, call her back.
dialogs.translated: She is truly an obedient lady. I beg you, my lord, call her back.

dialogs.original: Mistress!
dialogs.translated: Mistress!

dialogs.original: My lord?
dialogs.translated: Yes, my lord?

dialogs.original: What would you with her, sir?
dialogs.translated: What do you want with her, sir?

dialogs.original: Who, I, my lord?
dialogs.translated: Me, my lord?

dialogs.original: Ay, you did wish that I would make her turn.    Sir, she can turn, and turn, and yet go on,    And turn again.   And she can weep, sir, weep.    And shes obedient, as you say, obedient,    Very obedient.    (To DESDEMONA)    Proceed you in your tears.     (To LODOVICO)    Concerning this, sir    (To DESDEMONA)    Oh,well-painted passion!     (To LODOVICO)    I am commanded home.    (To DESDEMONA)    Get you away,    Ill send for you anon.    (To LODOVICO)    Sir, I obey the mandate    And will return to Venice.    (To DESDEMONA)    Hence, avaunt!
dialogs.translated: Yes, you're the one who wanted me to have her turn around and come back here. She can turn around all right; she's very good at turning on you. And she can weep, sir. And she's obedient, as you say, very obedient. [To DESDEMONA] Keep on crying. [To LODOVICO] About this letter, sir. [To DESDEMONA] Oh you are pretending really well! [To LODOVICO] I have been ordered to come home. [To DESDEMONA] Go away. I'll call for you later. [To LODOVICO] Sir, I obey my orders and will return to Venice. [To DESDEMONA] Get away from here! Away!

dialogs.original: Cassio shall have my place. And, sir, tonightI do entreat that we may sup together. You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus. Goats and monkeys!
dialogs.translated: Cassio will take over for me here. And, sir, tonight I ask you to have dinner together with me. Welcome to Cyprus, sir. Oh, goats and monkeys!

dialogs.original: Is this the noble Moor whom our full senate    Call all in all sufficient? Is this the nature    Whom passion could not shake?   Whose solid virtue    The shot of accident nor dart of chance    Could neither graze nor pierce?
dialogs.translated: Is this the same noble Moor that our whole senate thinks so highly of? Is this the person who supposedly could not be shaken by passion? The man whose solid virtue was invulnerable to anything chance or fortune could throw at it?

dialogs.original: He is much changed.
dialogs.translated: He has changed a lot.

dialogs.original: Are his wits safe? Is he not light of brain?
dialogs.translated: Does he still have his wits? Has he gone crazy, too?

dialogs.original: Hes that he is. I may not breathe my censureWhat he might be. If what he might he is not,I would to heaven he were!
dialogs.translated: He is as he is. I can't say a bad word about what he might be like. If he is not what he has the potential to be, then I wish to heaven he was!

dialogs.original: What? Strike his wife?
dialogs.translated: What was that about? Why did he hit his wife?

dialogs.original: 'Faith, that was not so well. Yet would I knewThat stroke would prove the worst!
dialogs.translated: That really was not so good. But I wish I could say that was the worst he'll do.

dialogs.original: Is it his use?Or did the letters work upon his bloodAnd new-create his fault?
dialogs.translated: Does he usually hit her like that? Or did the letter he was reading raise his temper and make him so angry that he hit her?

dialogs.original: Alas, alas!    It is not honesty in me to speak    What I have seen and known. You shall observe him,    And his own courses will denote him so    That I may save my speech. Do but go after    And mark how he continues.
dialogs.translated: Alas, alas! It is not right for me to tell you about what I have seen and learned. You will see for yourself, and his actions will show you what he is like, so that I don't have to tell you. Go follow after him, and just watch how he acts.

dialogs.original: I am sorry that I am deceived in him.
dialogs.translated: I'm sorry I misjudged him.
